title: Should I learn C++ and leave C or learn C first before going on to C++? - Quora

response.answer_text: As an uninformed kid who thought C++ was an update to C, and jumped to C++ from C, I think I am qualified to answer this question. If you are thinking the same thing, do not rush. What did you learn in C? Although C and C++ are different languages, they are from the same category. So if you have just started, you will not be completely shocked. What do you mean by learning C by the way? If you meant mastering the language it is going to take a lot of time. Learning a language is not the same thing as finishing a book. I remember reading my first C book. I didn’t have a computer and I didn’t even know I needed a computer! I read it like a novel, finishing it in 3–4 days understanding literally nothing. I then discovered it was actually a programming language… After that I did a research (not a good one… you will see) on programming languages. And when I saw C++, I was devastated thinking I wasted my time on another old language instead of learning the updated(!) version. But I didn’t give up. I started C++, however now the things were different. The language looks really similar to the good old C. My dumbass brain supposed that these were the unupdated parts of the language( Boy was I dumb ) and felt confident enough to not read them. However, the codes started to be incomprehensible really quickly. It felt different. While I was scratching my head I got my own computer and (finally) wrote my first code in the C language (because I already knew it right?) ERROR: unknown type name ‘using’ ERROR: ‘cout’ undeclared (first use in this function) WRONG. As you can see I knew nothing. I didn’t know C, I didn’t know C++. I was blindly reading them. This is not the way to learn these languages. I am now teaching C++ to small groups. I know that C++ is not the updated C now. But believe me or not, I still cannot comfortably program in C language. Knowing a language means using it. My native language is Turkish. However I do not know all the words in Turkish. Should I learn Turkish? No, I guess not. Should I leave Turkish to learn German? No, I guess not. If I to speak German for 20 years would I be able to speak Turkish this fluently? No, I guess not.

C is the default choice for source level programming, like kernel programming, driver development etc..C is somewhat better than C++ in speed and efficiency. It is easier to code and debug in C than C++. so, it is better to learn C Language before C++. C++ is by far more complex than C, it has a lot more stuff in the language itself, it has a bigger standard library, it performs a lot of implicit things that are not seen in the code, but, at the same time, it makes programming easier because all of those extra features.
